fields.title: Sacramento State’s Low Impact Development Tour
fields.description: In 2015, Sacramento State’s Office of Water Programs (OWP) and Facilities Management teamed with the City of Sacramento to install new stormwater management devices on campus. The devices, or low impact development best management practices (LID BMPs), are intended to reduce stormwater impacts to the American and Sacramento Rivers. Stormwater runoff from urban development is one of the leading contributors of water quality degradation. Take the tour to learn more.

fields.title: Thank you!
fields.description: Thank you for taking this survey!

fields.title: We appreciate your feedback!
fields.description: Thank you for taking the time to answer a few questions!

fields.title: State Board Disclaimer
fields.description: Funding for this project has been provided in full or in part through an agreement with the State Water Resources Control Board. The contents of this document do not necessarily reflect the views and policies of the State Water Resources Control Board, nor does mention of trade names or commercial products constitute endorsement or recommendation for use.

fields.title: Lot 7 Bioretention Planter
fields.simple_directions: Walk to the south side parking lot 7 planter.
fields.description: There are multiple bioretention planters in Parking Lot 7, and we advise caution if viewing them during peak school hours, as the parking lot is very active.

fields.title: Lot 7 Bioswale
fields.simple_directions: Move to the south side of campus, parking lot 7.
fields.description: The Parking Lot 7 bioswale runs along the parking lot exit, and runs East-to-West.

fields.title: Lot 10 Bioretention Planter
fields.simple_directions: Move to the Lot 10 student parking lot on the south side of Campus.
fields.description: Lot 10 is the Southwestern most parking lot for the CSUS campus, and it contains two bioretention planters.

fields.title: Library Green Rain Garden and Porous Pavement
fields.simple_directions: Follow signs to the Campus's library.
fields.description: There are two library green rain gardens, with one on either large patch of grass in front of the library.

fields.title: Calaveras Hall Roof Rain Garden and Porous Pavement
fields.simple_directions: Move around to the North Side of Calaveras Hall.
fields.description: This BMP site can be found on the Western side of Calaveras Hall, between it and Kadema Hall.

fields.title: Calaveras Hall Roof Drain and Rain Garden
fields.simple_directions: Walk to the west side of Calaveras Hall.
fields.description: Calaveras Hall is in the middle of the CSUS campus, just South of Douglass Hall, and West of Mendocino Hall. This specific BMP site is on the Northern end of Calaveras Hall.

fields.title: College Town Drive Rain Garden
fields.simple_directions: Walk over to College Town Drive.
fields.description: The College Town rain gardens rest in the Southwest corner of campus, on the West side of College Town Drive.

fields.title: Jed Smith Green Street
fields.simple_directions: Head toward the Jed Smith Green Street.
fields.description: Jed Smith Drive runs down the middle of campus, between Parking Structure III and the University Police Station.

fields.title: Guy West Bridge
fields.simple_directions: Head toward the Guy West Bridge.
fields.description: The Guy West bridge rests on the East end of campus, overlooking the American River.

fields.title: Porous Pavement
fields.description: Porous pavement is a paved, pervious surface underlain by a gravel storage zone.  The pavement consists of less fine aggregates than traditional concrete, and the larger pore spaces that result allow for temporary storage of runoff and a means for runoff to eventually drain into the gravel layer below.  In turn, the gravel provides an additional storage component and allows infiltration into the underlying native soils.  The porous pavement used for this project is approximately four to eight inches thick with an additional four to eight inches of gravel subbase.

fields.title: Bioretention Planter
fields.description: Bioretention planters are depressed landscapes into which runoff is directed and allowed to pond, filter, and infiltrate.  They consist of six to eight inches of ponding depth underlain by compost-amended soils and then a layer of gravel storage. The ponding zone allows for temporary storage of runoff and promotes infiltration into the amended soils.   These soils are a mixture of sand and compost specifically selected to filter and absorb pollutants.  The pores within and between the soil particles serve as storage for runoff as well.  Runoff eventually drains into the underlying gravel where it is stored and allowed to infiltrate into the native soils below (if the planter is unlined). A perforated underdrain is located at the top of the gravel storage area to allow runoff to discharge to the existing storm sewer in case the underlying soils and gravel storage become saturated.  A raised drain inlet is provided within the planter to serve as an overflow discharge point in case the runoff exceeds the planter’s design capacity. The overflow inlet is connected to the existing storm drain system.  The planter includes vegetation that was specifically selected to survive during periods of drought and still tolerate temporary inundation during the rainy seasons.  The plants promote evapotranspiration and therefore contribute to runoff volume reductions.

fields.title: Unlined Rain Garden
fields.description: Unlined, rain gardens are depressed landscapes into which runoff is directed and allowed to pond, filter, and infiltrate.  They consist of a few inches of ponding depth underlain by compost-amended soils. The ponding zone allows for temporary storage of runoff and promotes infiltration into the amended soils.   These soils are a mixture of sand and compost specifically selected to filter and adsorb pollutants.  The pores within and between the soil particles serve as storage for runoff as well.  Runoff eventually drains into the native soils below.  A raised drain inlet may be provided within the planter to serve as an overflow discharge point in case the runoff exceeds the rain garden’s design capacity.  The overflow inlet is connected to the existing storm drain system.  If the underlying native soils have good infiltration rates, the raised inlet may be omitted.  Sometime cuts may be made in the curb and gutter system to promote entry and overflow of runoff.  The planter includes vegetation that is specifically selected to survive drought conditions but still tolerate temporary inundation during and after rain events.  The plants promote evapotranspiration and therefore contribute to runoff volume reductions.

fields.title: Lined Rain Gardens
fields.description: Lined rain gardens are depressed landscapes into which runoff is directed and allowed to pond and filter.  They consist of a few inches of ponding depth underlain by compost-amended soils. The ponding zone allows for temporary storage of runoff and promotes infiltration into the amended soils.   These soils are a mixture of sand and compost specifically selected to filter and adsorb pollutants.  The pores within and between the soil particles serve as storage for runoff as well.  A raised drain inlet is provided within the planter to serve as an overflow discharge point in case the runoff exceeds the rain garden’s design capacity. The overflow inlet is connected to the existing storm drain system.  The planter includes vegetation that was specifically selected to survive the hot, dry Sacramento summers and tolerate temporary inundation during the rainy seasons.  The plants promote evapotranspiration and therefore contribute to runoff volume reductions.  Lined rain gardens are common at sites with very poor draining soils, or at sites with close proximity to buildings (so as to not cause adverse impacts to foundations).

fields.title: Bioswale
fields.description: Bioswales are long, narrow ditches into which runoff is directed and conveyed to a downstream discharge system.  Conventional bioswales provide treatment by allowing pollutants to filter and settle as runoff flows across the vegetated surface.  The campus bioswale design also promotes runoff to pond and infiltrate vertically through a subsurface layer of compost amended soil.  These soils are a mixture of sand and compost specifically selected to filter and absorb pollutants.  The pores within and between the soil particles serve as storage for runoff as well.  Runoff eventually drains into the underlying native soils below (the planter is unlined).  A perforated underdrain is located within the amended soil and connected to a drain inlet structure as a fail-safe in the case the bioswale does not drain; the underdrain’s valve is typically closed but may be opened if ponding becomes excessive.   The drain inlet within the bioswale is raised to promote ponding and infiltration and to serve as an overflow discharge point in case the runoff exceeds the bioswale’s design capacity. The overflow inlet is connected to the existing storm drain system.  The bioswale includes vegetation that was specifically selected to survive during periods of drought and still tolerate temporary inundation during the rainy seasons.  The plants promote evapotranspiration and surface filtration and therefore contribute to runoff volume and pollutant load reductions.

fields.title: Library Green Garden
fields.description: A cross-section of the Library Green Rain Garden and the porous pavement path that runs alongside it.

fields.title: Porous Pavement Parking Lane
fields.description:
A photo of the development of the Jed Smith Green Street site. Notice that the porous pavement is lined, so that the infiltrating water doesn't erode the foundation of the surrounding pavement. 

After this site was opened, campus delivery services notified the campus that the road was dangerously narrow now that cars were parking on either side of the road. The decision was made to remove parking on one side in order to allow for more spacing. As such, the East side of Jed Smith no longer accommodates parking.

fields.title: Existing Drainage
fields.description: Existing drainage could not be removed, as the system is still utilized (though in a lesser capacity). Enginers needed to plan ahead, and build around the existing system.

fields.title: Machinery
fields.description: Due to the weight of heavy machinery, and the role it can play in compacting underlying soils, it was requested that crews not such machinery. The message wasn't always passed down to those who were actually doing the work.

fields.title: Mislabeled Drawings
fields.description: Sometimes during excavation of a site, you find that previous contractors have mislabeled their drawings, which can lead to the unearthing of drainage pipes that are declared to be more than twenty feet away.

fields.title: Pathway
fields.description: Here, a backhoe carves out what would become the porous pavement pathway that leads through the Library Green.

fields.title: Gutter Cutouts
fields.description: Gutter Cutouts allow water that would normally have either been trapped on the road or funneled into the drainage system to instead run off of the road, and flow into the rain gardens that line College Town Drive.

fields.title: Curbside Cutouts
fields.description: Curbside cutouts allow water that would normally have been directed into the existing drainage system to instead drain into the newly installed bioretention planters. Doing so prevents hundreds, if not thousands, of gallons of water from being pumped into the American River.

fields.title: Rain Garden
fields.description: The Calaveras Hall Rain garden is specially designed, with every effort made to lead the water far away from the building's foundation

fields.title: Previous Landscaping
fields.description: Before the bioswale, this location was covered in grass, which is not drough-tolerant, and so had turned brown. The plants in his bioswale are drought and inundation tolerant, meaning they can go for extended periods of time without watering, as well as be submerged for many days without harm to the plants

fields.title: Site Features
fields.description: This bioretention planter retains and treats stormwater from a parking lot.  The planter was designed around the existing storm system infrastructure to minimize costs. The existing parking lots grades directed runoff to a drain inlet located in the middle of some parking stalls. Locating the planter around the existing drain inlet avoided the need for re-grading the parking lot.  The existing drain inlet and storm sewer below provide a means for overflow and treated discharge in the case all runoff from the storm cannot be infiltrated.  Click here to read about design and construction challenges common to all the BMP installations.

fields.title: Site Features
fields.description: This bioswale retains and treats stormwater from a driveway entrance to parking lot 7.  The planter was designed around the existing storm system infrastructure to minimize costs. The existing driveway grades directed runoff to a drain inlet located adjacent to a vegetated planter. The convention grass planter was replaced with a bioswale in which a new, raised drain inlet was placed and tied into the existing storn drain system below.  Locating the bioswale here avoided the need for re-grading the driveway.  Curb cuts were made along the length of the bioswale to allow runoff to enter.  The new, raised drain inlet and existing storm sewer below provide a means for overflow and treated discharge in the case all runoff from the storm cannot be infiltrated.  Click here to read about design and construction challenges common to all the BMP installations.

fields.title: Site Features
fields.description: This bioretention planter retains and treats stormwater from a parking lot.  The planter was designed around the existing storm system infrastructure to minimize costs.  The parking lot was originally graded to drain runoff to a valley gutter located in the center of the lot, where drain inlets collect the runoff and divert it to subsurface storm drains that discharge to a west drainage ditch.  The valley gutter and existing drain inlets were located in the middle of a drive aisle, making construction of bioretention planters impractical in those locations.  To resolve this issue and still make use of some of the existing infrastructure, bioretention planters were constructed within parking stalls closest to the existing valley gutters.  Additional gutters were constructed normal to the existing gutters to redirect runoff to the new planters.  The existing drain inlets were removed and new drain inlets were placed within the new planters.  The new inlets tie into the existing storm drain that discharges to the west ditch, and therefore allow a means of egress for overflows. Click here to read about design and construction challenges common to all the BMP installations.

fields.title: Site Features
fields.description: This unlined rain garden was installed to replace existing, lesser pervious grass lawn and thus provide more retention and infiltration of runoff from the surrounding landscape and impervious walkways.  This rain garden is unlined to allow runoff to infiltrate into the native soils below.  The garden was built around the existing drain inlet, which provides a means for overflow to discharge in the case all runoff from a storm cannot be infiltrated.  A porous pavement walkway was installed adjacent to the rain garden to replace the existing decomposed granite path that was disturbed during construction of the rain garden. Click here to read about design and construction challenges common to all the BMP installations.

fields.title: Site Features
fields.description: This unlined rain garden retains and infiltrates stormwater from a building roof top.  The original downspouts were directly plumbed to existing, subsurface storm drains, where roof runoff was directed toward and pumped over the levee and discharged into the American River. The rain garden was designed around the existing storm system infrastructure to minimize costs. To do this, the building downspouts were cut to disconnect them from the existing storm drain system.  Valley gutters were constructed under the cut downspouts to redirect runoff into the nearby rain garden. This rain garden is unlined to allow runoff to infiltrate into the native soils below.  A new drain inlet and storm sewer were built and connected to the existing storm system nearby.  The drain inlet and storm sewer provide a means for overflow to discharge in the case all runoff from the storm cannot be infiltrated.  Porous pavement was installed adjacent to the rain garden to replace the existing lawn that was disturbed during construction of the rain garden. Click here to read about design and construction challenges common to all the BMP installations.

fields.title: Site Features
fields.description: This lined rain garden retains and treats stormwater from a building roof top.  The original downspouts were directly plumbed to existing, subsurface storm drains, where roof runoff was directed toward and pumped over the levee and discharged into the American River. The rain garden was designed around the existing storm system infrastructure to minimize costs. To do this, the building downspouts were cut to disconnect them from the existing storm drain system.  Valley gutters were constructed under the cut downspouts to redirect runoff into the nearby rain garden. This rain garden was constructed in a fully lined concrete casing due to its proximity to the building; allowing runoff to infiltrate too close to the building can have adverse impacts on the foundation.  The existing drain inlet and storm sewer below provide a means for overflow and treated discharge in the case all runoff from the storm cannot be infiltrated. Click here to read about design and construction challenges common to all the BMP installations.

fields.title: Site Features
fields.description: This unlined rain garden was installed to replace existing, lesser pervious grass lawn and thus provide more retention and infiltration of runoff from the adjacent roadway and bikepath.  The garden was built by simply excavating a small area of existing lawn and underlying soils and replacing them with composted amended soils and specially selected vegetation that promote infiltration into the underlying soils (the garden is unlined).   Two cuts were made in the existing curbs along the road to allow runoff to enter and exit the garden, if flows exceed the garden’s capacity. Click here to read about design and construction challenges common to all the BMP installations.

fields.title: Site Features
fields.description: This street features a mix of unlined rain gardens, porous pavement, and conventional landscaping with water-wise vegetation.  The gardens and porous pavement were installed to allow infiltration of runoff into the native subsurface and reduce irrigation demands.  The existing heritage trees were maintained as they provide valuable tree canopy for preventing urban heat exchange.   The heritage trees and new gardens together provide soothing aesthetics that encourage pedestrian and bicycle use.   The rain garden on the west side receives runoff from the western parking lot, which previously discharged directly to the storm drain system.  The northern portion of the lot is drained into a cobble trench where runoff flows subsurface to the rain garden.  The existing storm drains were capped to allow the runoff to reach the rain garden.  The eastern rain gardens are interconnected such that runoff entering the northern-most and middle rain gardens flow to the southern-most garden, where a drain inlet can discharge any overflows exceeding the design capacity.   Subsurface piping juts diagonally west around the heritage trees to connect the rain gardens but protect the tree roots.  Porous pavement was installed along the east and west sides of the street which were converted to parallel parking stalls.  The design included 11-foot drive aisles in attempt to slow traffic and provide a more pedestrian- and bike-friendly vibe.  Unfortunately, based on feedback from delivery vehicle and bus drivers, these widths resulted in a perceived safety concern, and so the parallel parking along the east side of the road is now prohibited. Click here to read about design and construction challenges common to all the BMP installations.

fields.title: Site Features
fields.description: At this location, stormwater runoff captured from the eastern side of campus is pumped over the levee and pumped into the American River.  The runoff carries pollutants such as sediments, metals, and nutrients that adversely impact the river’s water quality and subsequently the beneficial uses (wildlife habitat, drinking water, recreation, etc.) the river provides.  During big storms, large volumes of runoff result in erosion of the stream bank and cause further degradation of habitats and water quality downstream.  To reduce these impacts, the university installed multiple stormwater retention and treatment devices, or low impact development best management practices (LID BMPs), on campus in 2014.  The types of LID BMPs implemented include a lined rain garden, unlined rain gardens, bioretention planters, and porous pavement.  These devices reduce the volume of runoff discharged into the river by allowing it to infiltrate on site.  Some of the devices include compost-amended soils that are specifically designed to filter and absorb pollutants, so runoff that is discharged is at least cleaner than had it not entered the LID BMP.
